simulated_ratings.title: Oppenheimer (2023)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Riveting, morally complex portrait of ambition and consequence that hit my sweet spot for weighty historical drama.

simulated_ratings.title: Berserk: The Golden Age Arc 2 - The Battle for Doldrey (2012)
simulated_ratings.feeling: The battlefield grandeur and tragedy are engaging, but the heavy fantasy action kept me a touch less invested.

simulated_ratings.title: Usual Suspects, The (1995)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Clever, twisty interrogation-room crime tale that scratched my itch for tight, mythic-tinged thrillers.

simulated_ratings.title: Hostiles (2017)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A stark, elegiac western journey with moral reckoning that I found gripping and humane.

simulated_ratings.title: Seven (a.k.a. Se7en) (1995)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Disturbing, unflinching crime horror that left me rattled and absorbed in equal measure.

simulated_ratings.title: Street Fight (2005)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Gritty, boots-on-the-ground political doc that felt immediate and eye-opening.

simulated_ratings.title: Louis C.K.: Live at The Comedy Store (2015)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Loose, intimate club energy with sharp, goofy detours that kept me laughing.

simulated_ratings.title: Secret in Their Eyes, The (El secreto de sus ojos) (2009)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Haunting, slow-burn mystery laced with longing and justice that lingered.

simulated_ratings.title: Interstella 5555: The 5tory of the 5ecret 5tar 5ystem (2003)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A stylish sci-fi music odyssey that’s cool and fun even if it’s lighter on character.

simulated_ratings.title: Two Family House (2000)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Warm, working-class dreamer’s tale with tender character beats that won me over.

simulated_ratings.title: Character (Karakter) (1997)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Flinty, father-son crucible of pride and class that satisfied my love for rigorous drama.

simulated_ratings.title: George Carlin: You Are All Diseased (1999)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Ferocious, insightful ranting that’s both hilarious and scathingly on point.

simulated_ratings.title: Léon: The Professional (a.k.a. The Professional) (Léon) (1994)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A soulful hitman fable with propulsive stakes and a surprisingly tender core.

simulated_ratings.title: Immortal Beloved (1994)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Romantic, stormy composer portrait that moved me more in moments than as a whole.

simulated_ratings.title: Sophie Scholl: The Final Days (Sophie Scholl - Die letzten Tage) (2005)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A searing, principled stand against tyranny that deeply stirred me.

simulated_ratings.title: V for Vendetta (2006)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Bold, ideas-forward dystopian rebellion that delivered rousing thrills with substance.

simulated_ratings.title: Ghost in the Shell: Stand Alone Complex - The Laughing Man (2005)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Cyber-crime intrigue with chewy ideas and slick action that kept my brain engaged.

simulated_ratings.title: Heima (2007)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Atmospheric, music-and-place reverie that soothed and transported me.

simulated_ratings.title: Million Dollar Baby (2004)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Unsentimental, heartfelt boxing drama that landed its emotional punches.

simulated_ratings.title: For All Mankind (1989)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Pure awe from real Apollo footage—humanity’s reach captured with quiet grandeur.

simulated_ratings.title: Best of Youth, The (La meglio gioventù) (2003)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Expansive, humane life tapestry that rewarded patience with deep feeling.

simulated_ratings.title: Logan (2017)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A bruised, intimate road-worn superhero tale that felt grounded and elegiac.

simulated_ratings.title: Twelve Monkeys (a.k.a. 12 Monkeys) (1995)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Mind-bending, melancholic time-loop mystery that I loved sinking into.

simulated_ratings.title: Young Poisoner's Handbook, The (1995)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Dry, darkly comic character study that’s unsettling and oddly compelling.

simulated_ratings.title: The Hound of the Baskervilles (1988)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Comforting Holmes mystery vibes, a bit slight but enjoyable.

simulated_ratings.title: Kitbull (2019)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Short, tender friendship story that hit the heart fast and clean.

simulated_ratings.title: Hamilton (2020)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Interesting insights and camaraderie, though it felt more supplemental than essential.

simulated_ratings.title: Let the Right One In (Låt den rätte komma in) (2008)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A hauntingly tender horror story whose quiet intimacy really got to me.

simulated_ratings.title: Goyokin (1969)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Spare, honor-bound samurai drama that resonated with my love for stoic moral tales.

recommended_movies: Norman Lear: Just Another Version of You (2016)
Before the Devil Knows You're Dead (2007)
Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows: Part 2 (2011)
Close Encounters of the Third Kind (1977)

simulated_ratings.title: Babe: Pig in the City (1998)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A surprisingly dark, tender city odyssey whose bruised compassion and oddball imagination moved me.

simulated_ratings.title: A Lesson in Cruelty (2018)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Mean-spirited party prank premise felt thin, with little of the sharp character insight I crave.

simulated_ratings.title: Alien: Covenant (2017)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Slick, brooding sci-fi horror with intriguing ideas that never fully gripped me emotionally.

simulated_ratings.title: Norman Lear: Just Another Version of You (2016)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Engaging, humane portrait of an artist who used comedy to wrestle with America’s conscience.

simulated_ratings.title: Zombiebox (2018)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A slog of half-baked skits that left me impatient rather than amused.

simulated_ratings.title: Arkansas (2020)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Offbeat southern crime yarn with a low-boil tension and odd humor I liked more in pieces than as a whole.

simulated_ratings.title: Before the Devil Knows You're Dead (2007)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A relentless, morally ruinous family tragedy that hit my sweet spot for taut crime drama.

simulated_ratings.title: Conspirators of Pleasure (Spiklenci slasti) (1996)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A perverse, wordless carousel of obsession that’s audacious, funny, and strangely poignant.

simulated_ratings.title: Anonymous Club (2022)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Intimate, vulnerable artist diary that quietly drew me in with its honesty.

simulated_ratings.title: Death at a Funeral (2007)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Breezy, well-orchestrated farce that delivers steady laughs without much afterglow.

simulated_ratings.title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows: Part 2 (2011)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A rousing, polished finale that satisfied on spectacle even if it didn’t linger for me.

simulated_ratings.title: The Stone Tape (1972)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Brainy hauntology with chilling ideas and atmosphere that scratched my love for conceptual horror.

simulated_ratings.title: Happy Bhag Jayegi (2016)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Sweet-spirited cross-border romcom whose charm is pleasant if lightweight for my tastes.

simulated_ratings.title: Killswitch (2015)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Clear, urgent doc about the stakes of the internet that kept my civic nerves humming.

simulated_ratings.title: Metal: A Headbanger's Journey (2005)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Curious, thoughtful tour through metal’s family tree that satisfied my love of cultural mapping.

simulated_ratings.title: M*A*S*H (a.k.a. MASH) (1970)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Sardonic, antiwar romp whose irreverence cuts nicely against the horror underneath.

simulated_ratings.title: Godfather, The (1972)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Majestic, inexorable crime saga that gripped me with its moral gravity and operatic tragedy.

simulated_ratings.title: Made in Paris (2006)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Relationship farce that grows messy and sour without enough depth to justify the spiral.

simulated_ratings.title: Runaway (2010)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Stylish, impressionistic music fable that captivated visually more than dramatically.

simulated_ratings.title: Wag the Dog (1997)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Razor-sharp political satire whose manufactured war felt uncomfortably plausible and richly entertaining.

simulated_ratings.title: What's Opera, Doc? (1957)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A compact burst of operatic parody that’s witty, musical, and joyfully overblown.

simulated_ratings.title: Deer Hunter, The (1978)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A harrowing, mournful epic of friendship and war that left me wrung out.

simulated_ratings.title: U.S. Seals (2000)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Generic, mechanical action beats with little character or texture to latch onto.

simulated_ratings.title: The Platform (2019)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Brutal, high-concept allegory that engaged my head and gut even when it bludgeoned its point.

simulated_ratings.title: Close Encounters of the Third Kind (1977)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Wonderstruck, humane sci-fi that balances awe with aching personal obsession.

simulated_ratings.title: Roots (1977)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Unflinching chronicle of siege and suffering that stirred my empathy and anger.

simulated_ratings.title: The Last Supper (2012)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Sweeping, bloody power struggle whose historical intrigue held me more than its action.

simulated_ratings.title: Wall, The (Die Wand) (2012)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Quietly profound survival parable whose solitude and nature reverie really resonated with me.

simulated_ratings.title: Austin Powers: International Man of Mystery (1997)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Goofy spy spoof with some clever gags, but the juvenile streak keeps it lightweight for me.

simulated_ratings.title: Austin Powers: The Spy Who Shagged Me (1999)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Bigger, louder, and thinner

simulated_ratings.title: Paranormal Activity 3 (2011)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Lean, well-executed found-footage chills that build dread effectively.

simulated_ratings.title: Pokémon: The First Movie (1998)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Colorful and brisk, though its simple moral and light character work keep me at arm’s length.

simulated_ratings.title: Kids in the Hall: Brain Candy (1996)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A sharp, oddball pharma satire that’s uneven but hits enough incisive notes.

simulated_ratings.title: Repo! The Genetic Opera (2008)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Brazen and operatic, but the campy rock-opera delivery kept me emotionally detached.

simulated_ratings.title: Sicko (2007)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Clear, urgent argumentation that engaged my civic outrage and curiosity.

simulated_ratings.title: Transformers: Revenge of the Fallen (2009)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Bombastic noise with little human texture or ideas to hold onto.

simulated_ratings.title: Austin Powers in Goldmember (2002)
simulated_ratings.feeling: The shtick feels reheated, with laughs scattered amid a lot of mugging.

simulated_ratings.title: Paranormal Activity 2 (2010)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Some effective tension, but it retreads beats without deepening the unease much.

simulated_ratings.title: Unforgettable Summer, An (Un été inoubliable) (1994)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A spare, morally testing frontier drama that quietly gripped me.

simulated_ratings.title: Bungo Stray Dogs: Dead Apple (2018)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Slick supernatural intrigue with energy, if not the depth I crave.

simulated_ratings.title: Ace Ventura: Pet Detective (1994)

simulated_ratings.title: How the Cossacks Bought Salt (1975)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Lively folk-tinged animation with playful invention that I enjoyed in modest measure.

simulated_ratings.title: Fahrenheit 9/11 (2004)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Provocative, polemical doc that stirred me even when it overreaches.

simulated_ratings.title: Casino Royale (1967)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Scattered spoof whose ideas are more amusing than its messy execution.

simulated_ratings.title: Transformers: Age of Extinction (2014)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Endless spectacle with thin characters left me uninvested.

simulated_ratings.title: Nutty Professor, The (1963)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Classic high-concept comedy with charm, if dated in spots.

simulated_ratings.title: The Minimalists: Less Is Now (2021)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Pleasant and clear-eyed, but a bit thin and sermon-like for lasting impact.

simulated_ratings.title: Death by Invitation (1971)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Conceptually intriguing but too creaky and uneven to really unsettle.

simulated_ratings.title: Shadow in the Cloud (2020)

simulated_ratings.title: David and the Elves (2021)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Sweet-hearted holiday fare whose sentimentality outweighs its substance for me.

simulated_ratings.title: On the Edge (2011)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Glossy, soapy crime melodrama with flashes of intrigue but limited nuance.

simulated_ratings.title: The Stranger (2010)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Generic amnesiac-thriller beats with little character heft.

simulated_ratings.title: Jupiter Ascending (2015)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Ambitious space opera worldbuilding undercut by clunky plotting and melodrama.

simulated_ratings.title: Fast & Furious 6 (Fast and the Furious 6, The) (2013)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Competent, glossy set-pieces with just enough camaraderie to coast.

simulated_ratings.title: The Fast and the Fierce (2017)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Thin, low-rent riff that never rises above its derivative premise.

simulated_ratings.title: Down Periscope (1996)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Light, affable service-comedy that goes down easy without leaving much behind.

simulated_ratings.title: Liberace: Behind the Music (1988)
